title: The Wickedness of Man and Noah's Ark
shortSummary: Genesis 6 reveals the increasing wickedness of humanity and God's decision to judge the earth with a flood. It introduces Noah, a righteous man chosen by God to preserve life through the building of the ark, marking a pivotal moment of divine judgment and grace.
timeline: Antediluvian period, traditionally dated c. 2500-2300 BC

keyCharacters.name: Noah
keyCharacters.description: A just and blameless man who walks with God; chosen to build the ark and preserve life from the coming flood.

keyCharacters.name: Sons of God
keyCharacters.description: Heavenly beings or godly descendants who took human wives, leading to the birth of mighty men and giants.

keyCharacters.name: Daughters of Men
keyCharacters.description: Human women who were taken as wives by the sons of God, contributing to the corruption of humanity.

keyCharacters.name: Shem, Ham, Japheth
keyCharacters.description: Noah’s three sons who, along with their wives, were saved in the ark to repopulate the earth.

definitions.definition: A phrase referring to divine or angelic beings who intermarried with human women, resulting in the Nephilim or giants.
Giants or mighty men of renown mentioned as the offspring of the sons of God and daughters of men.
A large vessel built by Noah under God’s instruction to preserve human and animal life from the flood.
A type of wood specified by God for building the ark; the exact species is unknown but denotes a durable timber.
A waterproof substance used to seal the ark inside and out to make it watertight.

outline.heading: The Increasing Wickedness of Humanity
outline.description: Humanity multiplies but becomes corrupt as the sons of God marry daughters of men, leading to widespread wickedness. God grieves over mankind’s evil, but Noah finds favor due to his righteousness.

outline.heading: Noah’s Character and Family
outline.description: Noah is introduced as a just man who walks with God, and his three sons—Shem, Ham, and Japheth—are named, setting the stage for the preservation of human life.

outline.heading: Corruption and Divine Judgment Announced
outline.description: The earth is described as corrupt and filled with violence, prompting God to declare His intention to destroy all flesh with a flood.

outline.heading: Instructions for Building the Ark
outline.description: God commands Noah to build an ark of specific dimensions and materials, providing detailed instructions to ensure survival through the coming flood.

outline.heading: The Covenant and Preservation of Life
outline.description: God promises to establish a covenant with Noah, instructing him to bring pairs of every living creature and sufficient food into the ark, and Noah obediently follows all God’s commands.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and its consequences, and seek to live a life pleasing to God like Noah did.
Trust in God's promises and obey His commands even when they seem difficult or unusual.
Understand that God’s judgment is just, but His grace provides a way of salvation for the faithful.
Cultivate a close walk with God, as Noah did, to find favor in His sight amid a corrupt world.

keyVerses.text: But Noah found grace in the eyes of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s mercy and favor toward Noah despite widespread human wickedness.

keyVerses.text: And GOD saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every imagination of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals the depth of human sinfulness that led to God’s judgment.

keyVerses.text: Make thee an ark of gopher wood; rooms shalt thou make in the ark, and shalt pitch it within and without with pitch.
keyVerses.significance: God’s specific instructions for the ark demonstrate His sovereign provision for salvation.

keyVerses.text: Thus did Noah; according to all that God commanded him, so did he.
keyVerses.significance: Noah’s obedience serves as a model for faithful submission to God’s will.
